Working Together for the Health of Your Heart

The mission of the Comprehensive Genetic Arrhythmia Program (CGAP) is to study and treat inherited heart rhythm disorders. Such disorders are also known as arrhythmias. While not all arrhythmias are genetic in nature, arrhythmias as a class represent a serious health risk. The most serious risk with arrhythmias is that of sudden cardiac death (SCD). Annually, nearly 500,000 deaths are attributed to SCD. Through its research, CGAP aims to provide a leadership role in the process of understanding existing genetic causes of cardiac arrhythmias, identifying new candidate genes, and applying this knowledge to improving partient care.

RECENT EVENT
Family Support Meeting 2018
Click here to see an Agenda
Click below to watch a recording of our 2018 event

  • Morning Presentations
  • Afternoon Presentations

OTHER FEATURE STORIES
Genes & Generations
Personalizing Medicine
Family Who Lost Daughter Finds Solace in Giving


Melding Experience - Expertise - Empathy

Experts in electrophysiology, cardiology, genetics, and genetic counseling work side-by-side to provide a multi-disciplinary focus not found anywhere else in the western United States. This focus is a significant benefit to both patients and their physicians for several key reasons:

  • Genetic causes of SCD can be rare and difficult to diagnose, and individual physicians often have limited experience recognizing such conditions. Our research team includes some of the the world's leading experts in inherited arrhythmias. Our expertise is available as a consultative service.
  • Inherited arrhythmias can affect not only the patient, but other family members as well, creating unique challenges in patient/family management. This is another area in which individual physicians can benefit from the experience of our experts. Our multi-disciplinary evaluations are designed to ensure that all patients and their families receive the best, most comprehensive evaluation possible.
  • Genetic testing and genetic counseling are recognized as critical components in making the right diagnosis, planning treatment, and helping patients and their families adjust to life with an inherited arrhythmia. For this reason, research genetic analysis and research genetic counseling is an integral part of our research efforts. It is also an important tool for researchers themselves, as inherited arrhythmias can only be understood within the context of family relationships.
  • Current advances in our understanding of the role that genetic mutations play in inherited arrhythmias reinforce the importance of patient/family management and the benefit of ready access to information from prior genetic studies. UCSF has a vast store of research data. CGAP intends to continue and extend this commitment as the boundaries of what we know expand.
Conditions Studied by CGAP

CGAP will study patients with:

  • Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia/Cardiomyopathy (ARVD/C)
  • Brugada Syndrome
  • Long QT Syndrome (LQTS)
  • Short QT Syndrome
  • Catecholamine-induced Polymorphic Ventricular Tachycardia (CPVT)
  • Aborted sudden death of uncertain etiology
The Power of Community

The goal of this website is to provide patients, their family members, their care-givers, and educators a place to turn for information, treatment options, and referrals. Here you will find information describing:

  • Genetic arrhythmias in general
  • How these conditions are diagnosed and treated
  • How our research programs work, what we are studying, and why
  • What clinical services are available
  • The expertise of our physicians and staff
  • How to make an appointment if you are a patient
  • How to make a referral if you are a physician
  • Links to other sites of interest

We hope you will use this site to help you better understand the implications of these complex genetic conditions. Our research will take "the hands and hearts"—and heads—of all of us to succeed. Your ideas are welcome. Please share them with us at cgap_study@ucsf.edu.

FAMILY SUPPORT MEETING 2013 — MAY 18, 2013

Click here for the agenda.

Links to Other Sites of Interest

(PLEASE NOTE: This list is for informational purposes only.)

  • Program in Cardiovascular Genetics, Division of Medical Genetics, UCSF
    http://www.ucsfhealth.org/geneticheart
  • ARVD (Johns Hopkins)
    Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia
    http://www.arvd.com
  • C.A.R.E. Foundation
    Cardiac Arrhythmias Research & Education Foundation, Inc.
    http://longqt.org
  • SADS Foundation
    Sudden Arrhythmia Death Syndromes Foundation
    http://www.sads.org

The Comprehensive Genetic Arrhythmia Program (CGAP) is a privately funded research effort that is the result of a generous gift from the Shaskikala and Dipanjan Deb family.

The first study funded through CGAP is our Genetics of Cardiac Arrhythmias study, focusing on the genetics of ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death (SCD). Key research goals for this study include:

  • Identifying new genes that are associated with arrhythmias and SCD
  • Determining how mutations in these genes cause cardiac arrhythmias

Much of what we anticipate learning from this program should improve our ability to recognize, diagnose, and treat these complex genetic conditions. Our program and its experts will be a valuable resource—unmatched in the western United States—for both patients and referring physicians.

Overview of Study Design for Genetics of Cardiac Arrhythmias

The Genetics of Cardiac Arrhythmias is an ongoing, single-center study focused on identifying new genes associated with inherited arrhythmias and SCD. It will use UCSF resources and laboratories for subject recruitment, enrollment, research genetic analysis, data collection and analysis, and follow-up subject contacts. Potential subjects of either sex and of any age or race may participate. Total enrollment is anticipated to be 400 subjects.

In particular, we are looking for subjects who:

  • Have a history of palpitations, fainting, or near-fatal cardiac arrhythmias that are not the result of physical damage to the heart; OR
  • Have been diagnosed with one of the six types of arrhythmias we are studying; OR
  • Are a family member of a person with one of the arrhythmias under study; AND
  • Have had a CLIA-certified clinical genetic test with results showing no known mutations; OR
  • Are a family member of an index (first) case who has had CLIA-certified clinical genetic testing with results showing no known mutations; OR
  • Have beed diagnosed with a hereditary arrhythmia syndrome for which on CLIA-certified genetic test is available.

Photo by Mark Estes

What You Can Expect If You Participate in the CGAP Program

Since the focus of this research is inherited arrhythmias, there is a strong emphasis on familial aspects. We hope to have the participation of the "index" case—the first family member with the condition who is brought to our attention—and as many relevant family members as possible. Evaluating family members can help us determine the right diagnosis and may be critical for finding the genetic cause of the arrhythmia.

Study participants can expect to receive the following:

  • Evaluation of your diagnosis by a multidisciplinary team of genetic arrhythmia experts
  • Research genetic analysis and research genetic counseling
  • Consultation offering evidence-based treatment plans tailored to your specific condition
  • Follow-up evaluation for the duration of the study, if desired, or consultation with your preferred provider.

Remember that BEFORE you can enroll in this study, you will need to show that you, or a family member, meet the enrollment criteria described above. The study team will ask for records of the clinical tests the doctors used, including clinical genetic counseling or clinical genetic testing, to help make the diagnosis in your family.

If you qualify choose to participate, you will be asked to provide a blood, saliva, or buccal cell specimen that will be used for DNA analysis. If your specimen shows a result that, in the best judgement of the study doctors appears to be of clinical significance or utility, your specimen will be re-tested by a CLIA-certified lab; this test will require a second DNA specimen. You will also be asked to speak with our genetic counselor to discuss what your results may mean. There are no other requirements for participating in this research study.

Participation in any research study is at-will: You can end your participation at any time, for any reason. You may also be asked to end participation if study management believes it is best for your health. All research performed at UCSF adheres to strict, federally-mandated guidelines for the protection of human research subjects and the proctection of personal health information.

Physicians and staff of the Comprehensive Genetic Arrhythmia Program (CGAP) are drawn from several different departments of the School of Medicine and provide a broad range of expertise in both clinical and research activities. CGAP team members are currently drawn from the:

  • Cardiac Electrophysiology and Arrhythmia Service
  • Division of Medical Genetics
  • Cardiology Division
Click here for Physicians  |  Click here for Other Program Staff

Physicians

Melvin Scheinman, MD
Chief of CGAP Clinic
Professor of Medicine
Walter H. Shorenstein Endowed Chair in Cardiology, UCSF

Dr. Scheinman heads up the CGAP Clinic and is one of the founders of modern cardiac electrophysiology. He is past president of the Heart Rhythm Society and serves on the editorial boards of many of the major cardiac journals. Dr. Scheinman has a long-standing interest in genetic arrhythmia syndromes and has published extensively on this topic. Recently he completed a sabbatical year at the Institute for Molecular Medicine at the University of California, San Diego, where he studied molecular and genetic mechanisms of cardiac diseases.

Degrees: MD, Albert Einstein College of Medicine
Clinical Interests: Catheter ablation, sudden cardiac death
Research Interests: Mechanisms of cardiac arrhythmias, new gene discovery for sudden cardiac death

Jeffrey Olgin, MD
Chief of the Division of Cardiology
Co-director of the Heart and Vascular Center
Professor of Medicine, UCSF

Dr. Jeffrey Olgin, a cardiologist and electrophysiologist, is Chief of the Division of Cardiology, and co-director of the UCSF Heart and Vascular Center. His main clinical interests include conduction disorders, arrhythmias, catheter ablation, implantable devices—pacemakers and defibrillators, atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, ventricular tachycardia, sudden death and supraventricular tachycardia.

Dr. Olgin’s basic research lab is focused on atrial and ventricular remodeling and how these processes occur to develop a substrate for atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia. He also has active studies in understanding the remodeling that occurs in the ventricle in the setting of heart failure and myocardial infarction to create the substrate for sudden death and ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation.

In addition, Dr. Olgin is involved in running the UCSF Cardiology Clinical Coordinating Center. He is the Principal Investigator for the VEST study, a multi-center, international randomized study to determine whether a wearable defibrillator vest can reduce the big early sudden death rate post-MI.

He is active in the American Heart Association, American College of Cardiology, and the Heart Rhythm Society, serving on several committees. Dr. Olgin is on editorial boards of major cardiology and electrophysiology journals and has authored several textbook chapters on arrhythmias.

Degrees: MD, University of Pennsylvania
Clinical Interests: Ablation and device therapies for arrhythmias
Research Interests: Mechanisms of atrial fibrillation, atrial remodeling

Robert Nussbaum, MD
Chief, Division of Medical Genetics
Holly Smith Professor of Science in Medicine, UCSF

Dr. Nussbaum is a board-certified internist and clinical geneticist and is the head of the Division of Medical Genetics in the Department of Medicine. His clinical practice includes General Genetics at UCSF and a number of specialized clinics such as the Program in Cardiovascular Genetics within the UCSF Heart and Vascular Center, the Cancer Risk Program and the Neurometabolic Clinic. He also serves on the Executive Committee of the Institute for Human Genetics as well as on the Executive Committee of the Biomedical Sciences Graduate Program.

Degrees: MD, Harvard Medical School
Clinical Interests: Cardiovascular genetics, inborn errors of metabolism, personalized medicine, pharacogenetics
Research Interests: Parkinson disease, Lowe syndrome

Pui-Yan Kwok, MD, PhD
Director of UCSF Genetics Core Lab
Professor of Dermatology, Henry Bachrach Distinguished Professor and Investigator, Cardiovascular Research Institute, UCSF

Dr. Kwok's research focuses on the development of tools for genetic analysis of whole genomes and applying these tools to understanding the genetic factors associated with common human diseases. Some of his on-going collaborative projects include studies of genetic susceptibility to psoriasis, atopy, narcolepsy, rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, hemorrhagic risk in brain arteriovenous malformations, and sudden cardiac arrest

Degrees: MD

Nitish Bahdwar, MD
Assistant Professor of Medicine, UCSF

During his training at UCSF, Dr. Bahdwar has done research on catheter ablation of focal atrial tachycardias using a new ultrasound-based 3D mapping system (RPM System). He has worked with Dr. Scheinman to describe the electrophysiologic characteristics of atrial tachycardia arising from the coronary sinus musculature. His current research focus is on the utility of equilibrium radionuclide angiography in assessing left ventricular dyssynchrony and optimal pacing sites in heart failure patients requiring cardiac resynchronization therapy. He is also doing research in describing unique electrophysiological characteristics in various forms of supraventricular arrhythmias and evaluating clinical efficacy of different catheter ablation techniques for atrial fibrillation.

Degrees: MD, Maulana Azad Medical College, Delhi, India
Clinical Interests: Mapping and ablation of supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias
Research Interests: Evaluating dyssynchrony with ERNA in patients undergoing cardiac resynchronization therapy; catheter ablation of atrial fibrillation; electrophysiological characteristics and diagnostic maneuvers in SVT

Byron K. Lee, MD, MAS
Assistant Professor of Medicine, Division of Cardiology
Cardiac Electrophysiology and Arrhythmia Service, UCSF

Dr. Lee is involved in several research projects that include looking at the genetics of specific arrhythmias. One project studies risk factors for sudden death following a myocardial infarction and another looks for genetic and non-genetic factors that predispose to the development of artial fibrillation.

Degrees: MD, Harvard Medical School; MAS, UCSF
Clinical Interests: Cardiac resynchronization therapy, lead extration, atrial fibrillation ablation, ICD and PPM implementation
Research Interests: Sudden death following MI, clinical trials, epidemiology of atrial fibrillation

Randall Lee, MD, PhD
Professor of Medicine, UCSF

Dr. Lee's training as an invasive cardiologist and a cellular molecular biologist uniquely positions him to investigate and develop new therapies and devices for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias and myocardial infarctions. He is active in the development of new technologies for the treatment of atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachyarrhythmias resulting from congestive heart failure. He is also interested in the cellular and molecular derangements that occur during cardiac arrhythmias and myocardial infarctions, using genetic engineering techniques to investigate derangements during these events. Additionally, he is interested in cardiac development of the conduction system and is presently investigating means to alter conduction that may then be applied to diseased states.

Degrees: MD and PhD, UCLA Medical School
Clinical Interests: Management and genetics of atrial fibrillation, risk statification, and treatment of patients at high risk for sudden cardiac death
Research Interests: Tissue engineering for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias and vascular regeneration

Greg Marcus, MD, MAS
Assistant Professor of Medicine, Cardiac Electrophysiology, UCSF

Dr. Marcus is a faculty member in the Electrophysiology section of the Cardiology Division at UCSF. He performs ablations for a variety of arrhythmias and device implantations. He performs clinical research, often with translational and genetic components, that help to understand the mechanisms underlying cardiac arrhythmias.

Degrees: MD, George Washington University School of Medicine; MAS, UCSF
Clinical Interests: Mapping and catheter ablation for atrial fibrillation, supraventricular tachycardias, and ventricular arrhythmias
Research Interests: Etiologies of artial arrhythmias, specifically serologic markers and genetic determinants important to the atrial substrate in atrial fibrillation

Zian Tseng, MD, MAS
Assistant Professor of Medicine
Cardiac Electrophysiology and Arrhythmia Service, UCSF

Dr. Tseng is expert in all aspects of electrophysiology, including ablation of complex arrhythmias, implantation of devices, lead extraction, and device treatment of heart failure (resynchronization). Current research includes identification of genetic risk factors for sudden cardiac death, risk factor modification, and the effects of neuromuscular incapacitating devices. Dr. Tseng graduated in 1998 from UCSF's School of Medicine, where he also completed a year of graduate studies in biomedical sciences. He later completed internal medicine, cardiology, and electrophysiology training at UCSF, where he is currently an Assistant Professor of Medicine.

Degrees: MD and MAS, UCSF Medical School
Clinical Interests: Sudden cardiac death, ventricular arrhythmias
Research Interests: Genetics of sudden cardiac death

Vasanth Vedanthan, MD, PhD
Assistant Professor of Medicine, Division of Cardiology
Cardiac Electrophysiology and Arrhythmia Service, UCSF

Dr. Vasanth Vedantham is a cardiologist and electrophysiologist specializing in the treatment of a wide range of heart rhythm disorders with medications, catheter ablation, and implantation of devices such as pacemakers and defibrillators. He also implants biventricular devices for cardiac resynchronization therapy in patients with heart failure. Dr. Vedantham earned his MD and PhD from Harvard Medical School in 2002, after which he completed internal medicine residency at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He then completed fellowships at UCSF in both cardiovascular medicine and clinical cardiac electrophysiology and joined the faculty in 2010. His research interests focus on the molecular biology of the electrical system of the heart, with the goal of making advances in basic cardiovascular science that will lead to improvements in the treatment and prevention of arrhythmias.

Degrees: MD and PhD, Harvard Medical School
Clinical Interests: Catheter ablation, implantation of pacemakers and defibrillators, cardiac resynchronization therapy
Research Interests: Molecular biology of the electrical system of the heart

Other Program Staff

Julianne Wojciak, MS, CGC
Genetic Counselor, Division of Medical Genetics, UCSF

Julianne Wojciak coordinates the Program in Cardiovascular Genetics, providing genetic counseling services for patients with hereditary heart conditions. She assesses a patient's medical and family history to determine the genetic nature of heart disease in the family, discusses the benefits and limitations of genetic testing and cardiovascular screening, and helps families understand and cope with the emotional and familial implications of inherited heart conditions. Julianne received her masters of science degree in genetic counseling from the University of Colorado, Health Science Center in Denver, Colorado. Prior to coming to UCSF, Julianne counseled patients and families at risk for inherited cancer syndromes and coordinated a variety of research studies related to hereditary cancer at UCLA.

Joan Campagna, CCMA-C, CPT-1, BS
Study Coordinator, CGAP Program
Cardiovascular Research Institute, UCSF

Joan Campagna works for the Cardiovascular Research Institute and is Study Coordinator for the Comprehensive Genetic Arrhythmia Program. In this capacity she assists the study team with subject recruitment and outreach; day-to-day study management; results tracking; compliance with UCSF, state, and federal regulations; and managing the the study website. Recent certification programs in Clinical Trial Design and Management, Clinical Medical Assisting, Phlebotomy, and Biotechnology Manufacturing compliment years in business in a variety of marketing support and marketing communications positions.

There are several treatment options available depending on the type and severity of your arrhythmia and the results of your clinical genetic testing. Your program team and your doctor will decide which treatment is right for you.

  • Medications - Certain anti-arrhythmic drugs change the electrical signals in the heart and help prevent abnormal sites from starting irregular or rapid heart rhythms.
  • Implantable Device (Pacemaker) - All pacemakers work on "demand" and are used to treat slow heart rhythms. They are small devices that are implanted beneath the skin below the collar bone and connected to a pace wire(s) positioned inside the heart through a vein; this delivers a small electrical impulse to stimulate the heartbeat when it is going too slow.
  • Catheter Ablation - A technique pioneered at UCSF, radiofrequency catheter ablation destroys or disrupts parts of the electrical pathways causing the arrhythmias, providing relief for patients who may not have responded well to medications, or who would rather not or can't take medications.
  • Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillator - An implantable cardioverter defibrillator is a device for people who are prone to life-threatening rapid heart rhythms. It is slightly larger than a pacemaker and usually is implanted beneath the skin below the collar bone. It is

    Dr. Melvin Scheinman
    Chief of CGAP Clinic
    connected to a defibrillation/pace wire(s) positioned inside the heart through a vein. It has the capability of delivering an electric shock to the heart when it determines the heart rate is too fast. It also is capable of pacing or stimulating the heart when it is going too slow.
  • Clinical Genetic Counseling - Being diagnosed with a genetic arrhythmia can bring up difficult emotions, including fears about sudden cardiac death, confusion about a new diagnosis, and worries about passing the conditon on to other family members. Genetic counselors are specially trained to help individuals and their families navigate these adjustments and to learn how to apply this knowledge to their future life choices. Genetic counselors will also help you sort out who else in your family could have an inherited arrhythmia.

node.Fname: San Francisco POstmortem Systematic InvesTigation of Sudden Cardiac Death (POST SCD) Study ./cardiology/research/programs/post/index.html
node.FileBody: Welcome! We are a clinical research laboratory with a multidisciplinary team and collaborations with local and federal agencies to comprehensively characterize the burden, underlying causes, and risk factors of sudden cardiac death in our prototypic, diverse U.S. community.

• Study Urges Better Heart Implant Device Tracking
  • Monitoring of Pacemakers, Defibrillators Underestimates Device Problems
  • Current Monitoring of Pacemakers, Defibrillators May Underestimate Device Problems
  • Tseng Receives Funding to Study HIV/AIDS, Sudden Cardiac Death
  • S.F. police chief seeks stun gun program
  • Are People with HIV/AIDS More Prone to Sudden Cardiac Death?
  • Sudden Cardiac Death Subject of Sweeping UCSF Study in San Francisco

• Sudden neurologic death masquerading as out-of-hospital sudden cardiac death
  • Sudden Death in Patients With Cardiac Implantable Electronic Devices
  • Sudden Cardiac Death in Patients With Human Immunodeficiency Virus Infection
  • Characteristics of Sudden Arrhythmic Death in a Diverse, Urban Community

Sudden cardiac death (SCD) accounts for 10% of total mortality and is believed to account for 60% of mortality from coronary artery disease (CAD) -- over 500,000 deaths -- in the United States each year. The vast majority of true SCDs are due to lethal ventricular arrhythmias. It is estimated that 80% of SCDs occur in the setting of underlying CAD, and the majority of SCDs occur out-of-hospital in patients for whom SCD is commonly the initial, lethal manifestation of CAD. Despite advances in pre-hospital care, bystander cardiopulmonary resuscitation, and early defibrillation, survival to hospital discharge remains below 20%. However, all of the above estimates of SCD using widely accepted World Health Organization (WHO) and Hinkle-Thaler epidemiologic criteria are based on antemortem data alone and highly nonspecific death certificates, and therefore do not accurately reflect its true incidence nor underlying causes.

In 2010, in collaboration with the San Francisco Office of the Chief Medical Examiner and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, we established the NIH-funded San Francisco POstmortem Systematic InvesTigation of Sudden Cardiac Death (POST SCD) Study, a first of its kind partnership between cardiac electrophysiology specialists and the County Medical Examiner to perform comprehensive autopsies for every incident out-of-hospital sudden death within the County of San Francisco meeting WHO criteria. We collect and review all antemortem medical history to recreate that individual's composite past medical history, and integrate these data with paramedic runsheets, toxicology, autopsy, and histology results. A panel of two cardiologists, two pathologists, a neurologist, an HIV expert (as needed), and a pediatric cardiologist (as needed), then adjudicate underlying causes for all SCDs. These rigorous investigations of nearly every incident SCD in an entire metropolitan area represent the most comprehensive study of its kind on the epidemiology and underlying causes of SCD.

HIV and Sudden Cardiac Death

In collaboration with Dr. Priscilla Hsue, we found that sudden death rates among HIV+ patients were about four times higher than sudden death rates in the general population, and accounted for 13% of all deaths among HIV+ patients. We recently received new NIH funding to identify risk factors and underlying causes of sudden death in the HIV+ population.

We are also working with Dr. Joseph Wong and Dr. Joseph (Mike) McCune to determine where the HIV virus is sequestered, which may have implications for cure.

Sudden Death in the Young (SDY)

We were selected in 2014 as one of only 10 sites nationally (and the only one of the West Coast) to participate in the CDC’s Sudden Death in the Young Registry, which aims to perform comprehensive pre- and post-mortem investigations of all SDYs in the 10 sites to determine its true causes and risk factors. The SDY Case Registry is a resource for understanding unexpected infant and child deaths. The registry provides comprehensive information about the circumstances associated with these infant deaths, as well as information about case investigations and their components.

Objectives:

  • Create state-level surveillance systems that build upon child death review activities.
  • Categorize SDY using standard definitions.
  • Monitor the incidence of different types of SDY.
  • Describe demographic and environmental factors associated with the different types of SDY.
  • Guide interventions and potentially save lives.
  • Improve systems of care for families.

Cardiac Implantable Electronic Devices

We recently reported that approximately 5% of all SCDs occur in patients who have a CIED (cardiovascular implantable electronic device), and half had device concerns (JAMA Internal Med. Article and UCSF press release). Our comprehensive post-mortem examinations of these devices can determine whether any malfunctions occurred that may have contributed to these sudden deaths. In the past, device problems have only been investigated as they occurred in living patients, and the most severe problems; those causing, contributing, or failing to rescue one from SCD, have not been captured because these out-of-hospital deaths are rarely investigated by medical examiners and coroners. Via the POST SCD mechanism and partnership we perform comprehensive post-mortem examinations of any sudden death with CIED to determine whether any malfunctions occurred in these sudden deaths. We are actively collaborating with the FDA to provide these unique data to help improve the design and utilization of these lifesaving devices.

Sudden Neurological Death:

Our research into all causes of sudden death revelaed a surprising finding that over 5% of all apparent SCDs are due to neurologic cause, a condition we have coined Sudden Neurologic Death. In partnership with UCSF neurologist Dr. Anthony Kim and NYU epileptologist Dr. Orrin Devinsky we are characterizing the risk factors and underlying causes of these SNDs, including fatal strokes, intracranial hemorrhages, and Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy (SUDEP).

Family Outreach Initiative:

Our comprehensive investigation, and the precise identification of underlying causes of nearly every SCD in San Francisco, allows us to satisfy an ultimate goal of POST SCD – preventing SCDs. Via our close interactions with the next-of-kin of SCD victims, we can target intervention for those at highest risk for future SCD: family members of SCD victims. Because some conditions predisposing to high risk of SCD are due to genetic mutations (e.g., hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or congenital long QT syndrome), we are designing a family resource, the Family Sudden Death Initiative, to help risk stratify family members and complete future genetic screening if applicable.

• Zian H. Tseng, M.D., M.A.S.
    (See his Faculty Spotlight profile here.)
  • Jeffrey E Olgin, M.D.
  • Phillip C. Ursell, M.D.
